column4: Hi everyone. Trying to get compiz up and running on Xubuntu. I installed nvidia-current and it works fine (I get full resolution and everything) but whenever I run nvidia-xconfig and generate a xorg.conf the system crashes.
does compiz force using xorg.conf?
are you sure your nvidia card is supported by nvidia-current vs. the old drivers?
I searched a LOT but it's a new card. Nothing shows up on google
you weren't kidding about results be thin for that card ;)  good luck man.
when you don't have xorg.conf in place, try "lspci -vnvn" find the VGA section, and the kernel driver in use line, i imagine it's gonna say nouveau instead of nvidia
output is : "Kernel driver in use: nvidia" followed by "Kernel modules: nvidia_current, nouveau, nvidiafb"
do you think I should just rename the driver to nouveau in xorg.conf?
well, that's the nvidia driver then!  so i was wrong.  not sure how that's possible without xorg.conf
NO, you probably want nvidia over nouveau
I'm chatting with you right now on full resolution on my computer booting without xorg.conf
that's a mystery to me.  Good luck.

by the way, search the hardware it seems I have to VGA controllers: 00:02.0 VGA compatible controller: Intel Corporation 2nd Generation Core Processor Family Integrated Graphics Controller (rev 09) AND 01:00.0 VGA compatible controller: nVidia Corporation Device 124d (rev a1)
AHHH you have one of those hybrid cards
what's a hybrid card?
intel/nvidia thing... you need some special software to use that properly i believe
oh boy, definitely not available on linux right?
it is actually - there are 2 options i believe, it's not hardware i have
do I have to remove nvidia-current before trying bumblebee
i'm not sure, sorry.
don't be, you've been very helpful. Thank you so much.
Dude, you are awesome. It's definitely a hybrid card and definitely a bumblebee solution.
awesome!
weird card for sure! From what I read, they just created it to reduce energy consumption by going through the intel interface
